qas.question: Whom found that they can make musical instruments sound more natural with an amplifier boost at the turnover point?
What is found when a complementary boost is used at the bass turnover point?
When frequency in the treble increases what happens to the recording amplitude?
What happens when frequency decreases in the bass?

context: In 1926 Joseph P. Maxwell and Henry C. Harrison from Bell Telephone Laboratories disclosed that the recording pattern of the Western Electric "rubber line" magnetic disc cutter had a constant velocity characteristic. This meant that as frequency increased in the treble, <a2_0>recording amplitude decreased<a2_0/>. Conversely, in the bass as frequency decreased, <a3_0>recording amplitude increased<a3_0/>. Therefore, it was necessary to attenuate the bass frequencies below about 250 Hz, the bass turnover point, in the amplified microphone signal fed to the recording head. Otherwise, bass modulation became excessive and overcutting took place into the next record groove. When played back electrically with a magnetic pickup having a smooth response in the bass region, a complementary boost in amplitude at the bass turnover point was necessary. <a0_0>G. H. Miller<a0_0/> in 1934 reported that when complementary boost at the turnover point was used in radio broadcasts of records, the <a1_0>reproduction was more realistic<a1_0/> and many of the musical instruments stood out in their true form.
